SIMON: Thank you very much Richard and Malcolm

that will be the Paul Baumann bit! Paul is

put the debate we always have about the NHS

389.text:
country actually think about our efforts over

worth remembering the very high public esteem

423.text:
nurses, therapists, doctors, other staff working

429.text:
we will hear, right across the country. We

437.text:

444.text:
couple of years. We choose the imaginatively

451.text:

Given all of the pressures and all of the

457.text:
debates, we felt it was very important to
focus on a smaller number of key national

464.text:
priorities that we would help contribute to
driving over the course of the next 12‑24

470.text:
months. So those five that we will be debating
here at Expo and constitutes the work programme

479.text:
of many people here in this room and they
are these. First, to improve A&E performance

487.text:
and the wider experience that patients have
of using urgent and emergency care services.

491.text:
And I'm going to be talking tomorrow a bit
about some of the pressures we can see over

497.text:
the coming winter and how we need to mobilise
around them. The critical responsibility that

505.text:
we at NHS England have for primary care services,
for GP services. The clear improvements you

511.text:
will hear about in the panel in a moment around
cancer and mental health services, all within

517.text:
a difficult financial environment that Paul
is going to describe. But recognising that

521.text:
just doing more of the same is no longer going
to work and therefore really the kind of essence

526.text:
of Expo is about doing things differently

531.text:
redesign is essential for that. Let me pick
out a few of those briefly, because I will

539.text:
have the opportunity to talk more tomorrow.

550.text:
year, including the year we are reporting
on 16/17, about 300 million times patients

556.text:
have visited their GP surgery over the course
of the last year. That compares with about

561.text:
23 million visits to A&E departments and other
parts of the system. What happens in primary

567.text:
care is really crucially important for the
NHS as a whole. And yet, if you look back

574.text:
a few years you see that we have not actually
acted on that insight. If you see what has

581.text:
happened to the growth in GP numbers, for
example, you can see that compared to the,

588.text:
quite substantial expansion that there have
been in hospital consultants, actually GP

592.text:
numbers have been falling. That is why NHS
England explicitly with the BMA, with The

600.text:
Royal College of GPs, are now embarked on
a programme to both increase investment and

606.text:
reform the way in which primary care services
operate. I think it is a source of modest

611.text:
pride in each of the years prior to NHS England,
GP spending was going down and now we have

620.text:
put a clear kink in the curve and in the early
stages of a significant shift in the resourcing

627.text:
and the design of primary care services. What
does that mean for the public? One of the

635.text:
most obvious expressions of that will be we
want to make it easier for people who need

639.text:
a GP appointment to get one. And that experience
has actually been worsening in recent years,

646.text:
hardly surprising given the position we have
set out. Instead, therefore, the rollout of

653.text:
easier booking, organised on hub basis, populations,
30,000‑50,000 and if you run into a GP or

662.text:
leader from Greater Manchester while you are
here at Expo, ask about the action they have

666.text:
already taken, this is not a plan for the
never, never, it is happening across Greater

671.text:
Manchester now, it is happening across London
now, and you will see it rolling out across

677.text:
the whole of the country over the next 18
months. We are going to hear in one of the

683.text:
panels, I think, about cancer and mental health
services. I won't steal the thunder there

688.text:
other than to say that in the case of cancer
services for example, we know that we need

695.text:
big infrastructure investments in radiotherapy,
which along with modern cancer drugs and cancer

701.text:
surgery is one of the three main ways in which
people with cancer get properly looked after.

707.text:

kicked off the biggest upgrade in radiotherapy

715.text:
LINACs that we have seen in over 15 years,

720.text:
Hospital here in Manchester to see the impact
of that, and that is happening right across

726.text:
England. On mental health services, sometimes
when you are in the middle of something you

733.text:
yourself don't see it, it takes the opportunity
to be seen as others see you, holding a mirror

739.text:
up to understand what is really going on.

743.text:

work now to implement the mental health task

749.text:
force describing England as being in the middle

most ambitious efforts to treat depression,

765.text:
on that. We know that as we embark on these
changes we have got to have consistency of

774.text:
offer in many of these areas, but we have

779.text:
country represents. And so we make no apologies
for the fact that we are deliberately trying

786.text:

mental health service, cancer services and

820.text:

824.text:
than administrative structures then you want

829.text:
wherever you find it. But I think, if Expo

836.text:
simply doing more of the same is increasingly

842.text:
for frontline staff and it is increasingly

the country are redesigning services they

we were particularly pleased to be able to

the vanguards, the parts of the country that

primary and community and social care and

country are seeing lower rates of emergency

to the winter pressures which rightly the

899.text:
on. So I hope that gives you a flavour, not

has gone on over the course of last year,

agenda we have set ourselves for the year

will now talk with you about, and we will
